awd_titl_txt: Lab-in-a-Fiber Optofluidic Platform: In-Situ Assembly and Response of Layer-by-Layer Polyelectrolyte Films in Confined Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is jointly funded by the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program (EPM) in the Division of Materials Research (DMR) and the Electronics, Photonics, and Magnetic Devices Program (EPMD) in the Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems (ECCS).

Technical Description: This project is a theoretical and experimental investigation to integrate layer-by-layer (LbL) assembly of functional polyelectrolyte thin films with a long-period grating structure inscribed in index-guided photonic crystal fiber. The integrated system represents a lab-in-a-fiber optofluidics platform by virtue of its high refractive index sensitivity and the feasibility for molecular/nanoscale functionalization in axially aligned cladding air channels. The research is designed to gain fundamental insights into distinct features of LbL growth in fiber and to probe the response of the LbL film to stimuli in confined geometry in order to demonstrate the feasibility of the integrated scheme for optofluidic sensors. Project activities entail (1) simulation of mode coupling in various lab-in-a-fiber configurations to determine optimal platform with the highest possible index sensitivity; (2) inscription of the grating structure with the simulation as a guide to realize mode coupling at prescribed resonant wavelengths; (3) deposition of LbL polyelectrolytes with different propensity to chain exchange with a multitude of parameters while measuring the shift in resonance wavelength in situ; and (4) evaluation of the pH response of polyacid-based hydrogels constructed via LbL in the lab-in-a-fiber platform. The central goals of this project are to (1) establish a novel lab-in-a-fiber optofluidics to study LbL deposition in situ; (2) provide important insights into the distinct features of LbL deposition and response in confined geometry; and (3) build a knowledge foundation for the exploration of lab-in-a-fiber optofluidic sensing.

Non-technical Description: The research component of this project is to investigate layer-by-layer thin-film growth inside a special type of optical fiber, photonic crystal fiber with long-period grating structure, and to study the response of the thin film to stimuli in confined geometry. The success of the project is expected to bring to basic and applied research community and potentially the market place a transformative lab-in-a-fiber optofluidic stimuli-responsive platform for scientific exploration and technological applications. From educational perspective, this project engages doctoral students, undergraduate students, as well as high-school students. Dissemination of research results is achieved via various channels, including peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, web posting, and case studies in classrooms.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the layer-by-layer (LbL) assembly of functional polyelectrolyte thin films and their response to stimuli in confined geometry is of critical importance in order to harvest their distinctive chemical and physical properties for a variety of applications in smart micro/nano devices and systems. Long-period grating (LPG) structure inscribed in index-guided photonic crystal fiber (PCF) or single mode fiber (SMF) offers a unique lab-in/on-fiber optofluidics platform by virtue of its high refractive index sensitivity and the feasibility for molecular/nano-scale functionalization on silica-based fiber surface. It has excellent prospect of filling in a major capability gap in in-situ LbL investigation and device development under geometrical confinement. We carried out a comprehensive theoretical and experimental undertaking to integrate LbL assembly with LPG as an innovative strategy to study the LbL process in situ inside the cladding air channels or on the outer surface of the cladding to gain insights of LbL growth and to probe their response to stimuli to demonstrate the feasibility of LPG/LbL as optofluidic sensors. Specifically, we simulated mode coupling in various LPG configurations using the full-vector mode solver to determine optimal LPG platform with the highest possible index sensitivity for both PCF and SMF; inscribed LPG using CO2 laser and a 120º reflection mirror for symmetrical irradiation with the simulation as a guide to realize mode coupling at prescribed resonant wavelengths; conducted LbL of polyelectrolytes with specific propensity on LPG with flow rate, and number of layers as parameters while measuring resonance wavelength shifts in situ to realize a powerful optofluidic testbed using drug delivery LbL thin film as a model system; and evaluated the pH response of polyacid-based hydrogels constructed via LbL in PCF-LPG to demonstrate the potential of PCF-LPG/LbL as pH sensors. We successfully established the parameters for PCF-LPG and SMF-LPG to achieve the optimal sensitivity for the in situ study of LbL processes both theoretically and experimentally.

Our novel research undertaking has provided important new insights into the significant potential of LPG platform in the design, construction, understanding and implementation of functional LbL polyelectrolyte thin films. When coupled with capillary microflow system, it enables a powerful lab-on-fiber optofluidic platform for real-time and in-situ monitoring of construction and drug release of the drug-eluting thin films at molecular layer precision as a robust physiologically relevant test-bed. From a broader perspective, the integrated LPG/LbL strategy serves to greatly advance the fields of LPG and LbL both in their individual merits and, more importantly, due to new opportunities their combination potentially brings about in LbL-enabled device development and systems integration for molecular-level sensing, real-time monitoring, and mechanistic understanding of dynamic events triggered by external stimuli.

Our research findings have been published in five peer-reviewed journal articles (with one more under review) and presented in four invited/contributed talks at technical conferences. The project was carried out in collaboration with the Institute of Photonics and Electronics, the Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic in numerical simulations and with MIT in the development of drug-eluting polyelectrolyte coatings. As part of the outreach, the PI organized and chaired an NSF Workshop on US-Czech Frontiers in Photonics in Prague, The Czech Republic (http://www.stevens.edu/ses/nsfphotonicsworkshop).
